case_name: Madan Mohan Damma Mal Ltd. & Om Prokash Manglik v. Corporation of Calcutta

facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 118 of 1959 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 118 of 1959.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated July 2, 1957 of Calcutta High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 101 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 2, 1957, of the Calcutta High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 101 of 1956 arising out of the judgment and order dated January 16, 1956, of the Second Court of the Municipal Magistrate, Calcutta, in case No. 208B of 1955.

facts.text: Calcutta High Court affirmed conviction under s. 462 of Calcutta Municipal Act, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by special leave against the Order of the Calcutta High Court affirming the conviction of the appellants Messrs. Madan Mohan Damma Mal Ltd., and Om Prokash Manglik, its Manager, under s. 462 of the Calcutta Municipal Act, 1951

facts.text: Messrs. Madan Mohan Damma Mal Ltd. (appellant No. 1) sent consignment of mustard oil about 499 maunds from Firozabad to Calcutta on December 25, 1954 in tank wagon No. 75612.

anchor.surface_text: sent a consignment of mustard oil, about 499 maunds in weight, from Firozabad, the place of manufacture, to itself, at Calcutta, on December 25, 1954, in tank wagon No. 75612.

facts.text: Tank wagon placed at Pathuriaghat siding Calcutta at 8.45 a.m. on January 3, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: This wagon was placed at the Pathuriaghat siding at Calcutta at about 8.45 a.m., on January 3, 1955.

facts.text: Dr. Nityananda Bagui, Food Inspector, took three samples of mustard oil from wagon after arranging purchase of 12 ounces for annas eight with Om Prokash Manglik (appellant No. 2) found near wagon.

anchor.surface_text: Dr. Nityananda Bagui, Food Inspector of the Calcutta Corporation, accompanied by certain police officers, went to that siding and took three samples of mustard oil contained in this wagon, after arranging with Om Prokash Manglik, appellant No. 2, who was found near the wagon, the purchase of 12 ounces of oil for annas eight.

facts.text: Samples sealed in three phials; one given to appellant No. 2, one sent to Public Analyst same day.

anchor.surface_text: He took the sample of oil in three phials. They were properly sealed. One of them was given to appellant No. 2. The other two were kept by Dr. Bagui. He sent one of them to the Public Analyst for examination, the same day.

facts.text: Ashit Ranjan Sen, Public Analyst, examined sample on January 3, 1955 but could not come to positive opinion; reported adulterated on January 4, 1955, detailed report January 24, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Ashit Ranjan Sen, the Public Analyst, examined the oil contained in that phial on January 3, 1955, but could not come to any positive opinion about its purity. ... Mr. Sen reported on January 4, 1955, that the oil was adulterated. He sent a detailed report about the result of the examination on January 24, 1955.

facts.text: Tank wagon seized by Dr. Bagui that evening, sealed, left in custody of appellant No. 2.

anchor.surface_text: Dr. Bagui, however, seized the tank wagon that evening, sealed it with the Corporations seal and left it in the custody of appellant No. 2.

facts.text: Oil removed to appellants' godown on January 6, 1955; godown lock sealed.

anchor.surface_text: The oil in the tank was allowed to be removed to the godown of the appellants on January 6, 1955. The lock of the godown was then sealed with the seal of the Corporation.

facts.text: Dr. Bagui filed complaint against appellants on February 4, 1955 for selling and keeping for sale adulterated mustard oil.

anchor.surface_text: On receipt of the report about the mustard oil being adulterated, Dr. Bagui filed a complaint against the appellants on February 4, 1955, with respect to their selling and keeping for sale mustard oil, a sample of which was found on analysis to be mustard oil which was adulterated with groundnut oil.

facts.text: Trial court ordered despatch of third sample to Director of Health Services, WB; analyzed by Dulal Chandra Dey, found adulterated with groundnut oil.

anchor.surface_text: During the course of the trial, the trial Court, on an application on behalf of the appellants, ordered the despatch of the third sample phial of the oil in the custody of the Corporations Health Officer, to the Director of Health Services, Government of West Bengal, for analysis and report. This sample was analysed by Dulal Chandra Dey, Court Witness number 1, and found to be adulterated with groundnut oil.

facts.text: Appellants sent their sample to Om Prakash, Oil Expert UP Govt, who reported July 27, 1955 it conforms to Agmark, free from adulterants; report not proved.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants appear to have sent the sample of oil in their possession to Om Prakash, Oil Expert to the U.P. Government, who reported on July 27, 1955, that the sample conforms to Agmark Specification for Mustard Oil and is considered to be free from adulterants such as sesame, groundnut and linseed oil. This report, however, has not been proved.

facts.text: Deputy Commissioner of Police sent sample January 10, 1955 to S.N. Mitra, who reported it approximates genuine mustard oil based on saponification 173.3, iodine 105.

anchor.surface_text: The Deputy Commissioner of Police, Enforcement Branch, Calcutta, sent a sample of mustard oil on January 10, 1955, to the Public Analyst, Food Water, West Bengal Public Health Laboratory. Sri S. N. Mitra, D. W. 7, examined this sample and reported, on the basis of its saponification value to be 173.3, and iodine value to be 105, that the sample approximated to the standards of genuine mustard oil.

facts.text: Courts below found mustard oil in appellants' tank wagon adulterated with groundnut oil.

anchor.surface_text: The Courts below found on the evidence that the mustard oil in the appellants tank wagon was adulterated with groundnut oil, that the appellants were in possession of that oil and had stored that oil for sale,

facts.text: Supreme Court holds mustard oil adulterated based on analyses by Sen (BR Index 60.4, Bellier test positive at 28C) and Dey (saponification 175.5, iodine 106.8, turbidity 27C).

anchor.surface_text: Ashit Ranjan Sen, P.W. 2, Public Analyst, who examined the first sample sent by Dr. Bagui on January 3-4, 1955, found it adulterated, on the basis of the data that the B. R. Index at 40 degree C was 60.4 and the Belliers test for groundnut oil was positive inasmuch as it gave turbidity at 28 degree C. Court Witness number 1, Dulal Chand Dey, who actually analysed the sample sent by the Court, also found it adulterated, on the basis of his obtaining the saponification value to be 175.5, iodine value to be 106degree 8 and the appearance of turbidity at 27 degree C.

facts.text: Appellants were in possession of the oil when sample taken; manager took delivery prior to inspection.

anchor.surface_text: On the evidence on the record we are of opinion that they were in possession of the mustard oil. The consignment of oil was from the manufacturing firm, appellant number 1, to itself at Calcutta. Its manager, appellant number 2, took delivery of the wagon from the railway authorities on January 3, 1955.

facts.text: Presumption under sub-s. 4 of s. 462 that oil stored for sale not rebutted.

anchor.surface_text: the presumption that the mustard oil was stored for sale by the appellants, under sub-s. 4 of s. 462 of the Act, is rebuttable and has been fully rebutted ... We are therefore of opinion that this letter Exhibit R, or the arrangement which led to such communication, does not establish that the mustard oil in the wagon which will be otherwise presumed to be stored for sale by the appellants, was not stored for sale.

facts.text: Letter Exhibit R sent by appellant No.1 to Secretary U.P. Oil Millers Association at 10 a.m. January 3, 1955 requesting sample and test before delivery.

anchor.surface_text: Letter Exhibit R was sent on behalf of appellant number I to the Secretary of the U. P. Oil Millers Association at 10 a.m., on January 3, 1955. The letter said Please arrange for sample and test through the proper authorities concerned, so that we may take the delivery of oil only if it is found pure on analysis.

facts.text: Conviction of appellants under s. 462 correct.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the conviction of the appellants of the offence under s. 462 of the Act is correct.

facts.text: Judgment of Second Court of Municipal Magistrate dated January 16, 1956 in case No. 208B of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the judgment and order dated January 16, 1956, of the Second Court of the Municipal Magistrate, Calcutta, in case No. 208B of 1955.

facts.text: Police took one sample sealed with Corporation seal, as per Kalidas Ganguli.

anchor.surface_text: He stated that the Corporation Food Inspector took three samples and the police took the one sample which was sealed with the Corporation seal.

facts.text: Mahendra Kumar Gupta, chemist of appellants' mill, deposed he took sample and found genuine.

anchor.surface_text: Mahendra Kumar Gupta, D.W. 1, Chemist of the appellants mill, deposed however that he had taken the sample of the oil sent in that wagon and found it to be genuine mustard oil, free from any adulteration.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 2, 1957, of the Calcutta High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 101 of 1956
under s. 462 of the Calcutta Municipal Act, 1951 W. B. XXXIII of 1951 hereinafter called the Act.

holdings.text: the finding of the Courts below that the mustard oil in the appellants tank wagon was adulterated is correct

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances, the finding of the Courts below that the mustard oil in the appellants tank wagon was adulterated is correct.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Chemical tests by Ashit Ranjan Sen (B.R. Index 60.4 at 40C, Bellier test positive turbidity at 28C) and Dulal Chandra Dey (saponification 175.5, iodine 106.8, turbidity 27C) confirm adulteration with groundnut oil; Mitra's report on different sample does not contradict.

holdings.text: the appellants were in possession of the oil in the tank wagon when Dr. Bagui took samples of the oil from it

anchor.surface_text: We therefore hold that the appellants were in possession of the oil in the tank wagon when Dr. Bagui took samples of the oil from it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Consignment sent by appellant No.1 to itself; manager (appellant No.2) present, wagon opened for sampling, freight paid, railway custody would prevent access otherwise; not disputed in High Court.

holdings.text: this letter Exhibit R, or the arrangement which led to such communication, does not establish that the mustard oil in the wagon which will be otherwise presumed to be stored for sale by the appellants, was not stored for sale

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that this letter Exhibit R, or the arrangement which led to such communication, does not establish that the mustard oil in the wagon which will be otherwise presumed to be stored for sale by the appellants, was not stored for sale.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Presumption under s.462(4) rebuttable but letter only requests test before delivery, silent on non-sale if impure; no legal restraint from selling adulterated oil; no arrangement with Corporation; arrangement with police ineffective as no certificates provided.

holdings.text: the conviction of the appellants of the offence under s. 462 of the Act is correct

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the conviction of the appellants of the offence under s. 462 of the Act is correct.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Oil adulterated, appellants in possession, presumption of storing for sale not rebutted, satisfying elements of offence under s.462 Calcutta Municipal Act 1951.

justification_sets.label: Sub-section 4 Section 462 Calcutta Municipal Act 1951 support

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the companyviction of the appellants of the offence under s. 462 of the Act is companyrect.

outcome.relief_summary: Conviction of the appellants under s. 462 of the Calcutta Municipal Act upheld; all contentions rejected
